quotes.quote: Feelings of superiority always stem from an illusion.
The superiority of one mind over another depends on the rapidity with which experiences are thus organised.
Dominance is only for God.
The superior man is he who develops, in harmonious proportions, his moral, intellectual and physical nature.
Permanent superiority has never been realized by any nation in history. After the rise comes the fall.
Many a superior brain is blockaded by inferior thoughts.
There is no such thing as human superiority.
It is one mark of a superior mind to understand and be influenced by the superiority of others.
The way of a superior man is threefold: virtuous, he is free from anxieties; wise, he is free from perplexities; bold, he is free from fear.
Whoever envies another confesses his superiority.
Continuously feeling superior is a characteristic of immaturity.
The superiority of some men is merely local. They are great because their associates are little.
It is always legitimate to wish to rise above one's self, never above others.
Cool superiority as a mask for overflowing insecurity.
A wise man is superior to any insults which can be put upon him, and the best reply to unseemly behavior is patience and moderation.
Tolerance is the assumption of superiority
In every society some men are born to rule, and some to advise.
The greatest threat to compassion is the temptation to succumb to fantasies of moral superiority.
Whatever makes us feel superior to other people, whatever tempts us to convey a sense of superiority, that is the gravity of our sinful nature, not grace.
It is not true that people are naturally equal for no two people can be together for even a half an hour without one acquiring an evident superiority over the other.
Most do violence to their natural aptitude, and thus attain superiority in nothing.
Racial superiority is a mere pigment of the imagination.
There are a lot of people who are doing wonderful things, quietly, with no motive of greed, or hostility toward other people, or delusions of superiority.
One of the easiest ways to dominate a man is to demand something he cannot supply.
Superiority commits to protect those inferior.
Feelings of inferiority and superiority are the same. They both come from fear.

The superior man is the providence of the inferior. He is eyes for the blind, strength for the weak, and a shield for the defenseless. He stands erect by bending above the fallen. He rises by lifting others.
One must change one's tactics every ten years if one wishes to maintain one's superiority.
Superiority is always detested.
The superior man thinks always of virtue; the common man thinks of comfort.
